influenced by a theoretical perspective called appraisal Theory and I think if you're a computer scientist appraisal
theory for for some reasons you'll see in the moment is actually a very nice theory for building computational
artifacts but in a kind of brief overview the way appraisal Theory argues
is that emotion is this relational construct it arises not just from things inside of us but the relationship
between things inside of us and events in the world so let's say I want to be a mad scientist and I fail my first math test
then appraisal Theory argues I judg the relationship between that event and my goals along certain Dimensions was a
good or bad probably bad uh did I expect to fail the test uh how much control do
I have over it and who do I blame myself for the teacher for example and based on those patterns of appraisals that will
tend to elicit certain emotional responses but further it'll help shape how I respond to that emotional event so
if I feel I have control over that situation I may Double Down hire a tutor try to do better next time or I may
decide I have no control over what's going on in this classroom and join a band give up my goal of being a mad
scientist now if you're a computer scientist uh what you should notice is these kind of what are called appraisal
variables actually map on pretty closely to some well understood Concepts in computer science like utility
probability planning credit assignment and so part of what we did Stacy and
myself is reconstrued those appraisal constructs into these well understood
Concepts in computer science and so we basically showed how to remap different
